The last 30 mins are some of the hardest moments one could have seen on an IMAX screen (way back when those were a thing). The fact that this movie was packaged as a summer blockbuster in 2015 is a decision so absurd you almost think that it was by design.
Films about how life has no purpose usually make that the point of their stories (look at "A Serious Man" as an example) but "Everest" doesn't tell you that. It simply shows life as a no pre-destined goal world and the people who search for purpose in it.
That might be a more complicated depiction in film, but it also leaves one wonder why to sit down and experience that? What is to be earned? What is to be enjoyed even?
Perhaps just the view.

I give films a vote of above 7-8 really seldom and let me begin with explaining how I rate them. At the beginning I consider the film to be perfect with 10 points. But in process of watching film I deduct point by point for some minor aspects. Most common minor aspects are stupid dialogs, stupid acting, weak places of plot, absolutely unrealistic moments. That tally 7-8 point for the greatest films of nowadays. Getting down to our film, I had almost no reason to deduct any of points for the above-mentioned minors. Everything in film is nearly perfect. The film begins with absolutely outstanding shots of the Himalayas. Every technical part of film (sound, picture, editing) is perfect. In such kind of films it is more than important to have a viewer deep in the atmosphere. The plot was written very carefully, due to the multiple sources, such as books of the participants of the notorious climbing, which took place on Everest mount in 1996, documentary film (1998) and true facts. I can't imagine plot to be any better, because it is always hard to adopt true story for a film, especially with a genre like this. But there are still a few shots, I consider shouldn't have taken place in this film. That goes to "not perfect plot" and the reason of vote 9 out of 10. At the same time film is not overextended, I would even say it is rather brief, keeping you near the screen all the time.I will not tell much about acting, it is just very impressive. And there is not unrealistic exaggerations in the film. It also contains some moral about a lot of things, shown in small dozes. The movie is very colorful and simply beautiful, you can enjoy Himalayas all through the film. I watched it in 2D and can assure you, it looks much better this way, don't bother yourself with 3D version!

Review title: Good, but hides the true horror
Review_body: Everest is a very, very harsh place. It feels like for the major duration, the true harshest and bitterness is painted over. Reading a few blogs uncovers horrors this film doesn't even remotely touch on. Early scenes almost float around 'The Beach' - people partying, having fun. There's no true connection to the sacrifices that people have made to be there. Yes, it costs upwards of $50k - what was the true cost of earning that money to buy your way in?Yes, it's verging on EPIC. Yes, the audio is fantastic. Yes, the visuals are superb. Yes, you probably will enjoy it.It just constantly feels like a very missed opportunity to tell the true story of people who have died chasing a dream that probably can't be completely fulfilled.If you want to see 'real' mountaineering, watch 'Touching the Void'.6.9/10

I had the normal hopes that anyone would have for a movie of this kind. I did not have extremely high hopes, but they were not low, too. We'll have to admit that the film is visually stunning and presents a very good cinematography. The acting is quite good and solid, but not out of this world, like you should expect in an Oscar bait film, that after watching it, I believe it might get nominated for Best Sound Editing. The story is, indeed, powerful, but it didn't live up to itself. You should expect powerful intense scenes of survival and near death in a film about climbing the Everest, but you DO NOT get it. It causes nail biting at times, but it never lives up to the gut-wrenching film that you'd want to see here.In the end is a 7/10. A reasonable cinematic afternoon that you can give yourself. I had given 6.5 but I rounded it up to 7. Something that you can expect is that the film is, sadly, very forgettable. EDIT: After further analysis, I believe that the film does not deserve a 7. Therefore I'm reducing it to a 6/106/10

This is my poetic essay is dedicated to climbers from different countries and times, and the creators of this film."... Nature was silent. Soothing silence covered mountains. The sun began to warm the slopes and from time to time by slip on the ice or the pebbles or the icicles. Both ligaments worked in silence and were concentrated. These were moments of pleasure in mountaineering - you work and all the pores feel freedom and unity with nature, feeling like a small part of it. All the everyday worries seem minor at this time, and you realize that neither they should dictate your course of action in life. It is in such moments, like a true believer in the confessional, you are cleansed from the filth.I thought by us, top right, bottom left whizzed across the ice stone. A moment later, I heard a terrible bottom, tearing the silence, the gnashing of metal on the ice. Not knowing yet what this means, without turning around, I looked down. Only that there were guys, and now on the icy slope does not. But then over the rocks, trailing slope leaped first one body .... and disappeared, and almost immediately, apparently yanked the rope thrown or hit the rocks, the second .... and also disappeared. They are not hacked to death on the ice .... it was the end.... Scared silly! It is absurd! A moment - and everything is different. Not feeling all this, it is impossible to understand our condition. Then there was a strange thought: how did his doctoral, because it is already scheduled for October? And what about his son, because he is down in the camp, waiting for his father? And his mother - even today, he said that he was worried about her - and left her in poor condition? .. "From the memoirs of Soviet Scientist and Climber and also a descendant of the great scientist E. Tamm. Where he wrote, as on his eyes ended the life in the Himalayan foothills of the Soviet founder of cybernetics, the creator of the first recognition in the application of a mathematical modeling of physiological processes, the famous climber Michael Bongard.... Everest. Kailash, Shambhala, the treasure cave of Mata-Tash, mysterious Giants caves of Tibet, waiting quantum ascension of the human race, and while in China against them in their mind are struggling "cultural revolutionaries" , peacefully sleeping under the Song of Whales and Dolphins, that does not take an ear human; cybernetics, artificial intelligence, and all the breakthroughs of scientists on tops of the World and the rise whether Himalayan Kumai (huge eagle), or mind over matter, and merge with the Ocean of Vyacheslav Kurilov, the first Soviet Yogin, who mastered levitation, jumping off a Soviet ship in 1974 and sailed for three days in a storm in The Pacific to Philippine Islands, and got to the shore alive - all of these Generation of 1970's years, which gave the world the first climbers and created a noosphere, returned Buddhism led to the Altar of the Divine by translations of Tolkien and Lewis and awakened dignity after Stalinism, and incomprehensible, magical Reverence awareness Harmony of the Универсе came themselves and brought us to a breakthrough in science, and in the consciousness and conscience - and all of That Garmony of Heaven now suddenly falls into solemn silence and a vacuum in the film "Everest". And cathartic film merges with catharsis of Chomolungma.That is something elusive and make you watch this film,and one day or two to walk and think and be silent, and not to tell anyone a single word - because the soul is so full of something beautiful that you do not want to spill it, and the film Kormákur "Everest" is the visionary.A little hurt by the fact that, as is always the case in life, one love was stronger than the other, one resurrected man and brought him back to even greater accomplishments (Rob Hall 5 times to conquer Everest, and one time with Jen, that was a shamanistic how she led him out of the gloom of life), and the another ... no, could not, but gave his daughter name. But the beauty of their souls - merged with the beauty of God in the paintings of Roerich, and we stood in awe transcendent, so what do we need more? ... And now, a little bit more, and all the dead climbers will rise and we will be dissolved in the bliss of their superhuman consciousness, whether it is a celebration of Maitreya that predicted Roerich, or the Second Coming, or exocortex that made Dr. Will Custer from "Transcendence ". Or will come Giants Atlanta and Lemurian the caves of Tibet and sing us a song of universal brotherhood, love and forgiveness - that is what is can read in the keen eyes of Scott by Jake Gyllenhaal, impenetrable behind the lenses of sunglasses. And maybe about it is stratospheric loneliness Antoine De Saint-Exupery: cruel and hopelessly in his "Terre Des Hommes".And in this symphony I hear another voice, the voice of artists from the "Razor Blade" by Ivan Efremov in Tibet: "For millions of years, Calpe Calpe for ocean-blind, meaningless life splashing on the face of the Earth and God knows how many more worlds. Hundreds of thousands of years of existence half-beasts-half people went silent boiling passions and dark thoughts, no turning back, no climbing up and down. And so it went - not related to the past, not thinking about the future, disappearing in the present, like a leaf in the wind. But he had to cope with the evil in his heart, to break through it, as it had to do and he was in a new era of human power, still in the thrall of the old rage "...Ascension.

Review title: Just like the mountain, this will kill you
Review_body: As i was watching Everest i had a strange feeling i was about to share the fate of some of the characters in this movie, that i wouldn't make it. And sure enough my journey up Everest lasted roughly 80 mins. I understood that this mountain movie was not going to be in the same vein as flicks like Cliffhanger or Vertical Limit, so i was quite interested in this movie as i thought it would be a deep driven character narrative story not some lame absolute soul sucking dreck of a movie. From the get go this flick had no hope as the actors involved were lumped in to performing some of the most laughable dialogue i have heard in any movie for a long time and once they finally decided to leave one of the 3000 base camps they continuously traveled between and begin the ascent up Everest it turned in to an even more hilarious clichéd piece of crap. The only saving grace for this movie is the drop dead gorgeous camera work that captures the beauty of such a harsh environment, but i'm sorry i need a bit more in a movie then just that. I must note as well due to the quality of actors i thought that at least the individual performances would bring something to the table,but i was wrong. I have seen better acting from extras in porno movies so this would have to go in the back of the resume of every involved. Overall just a horrible experience and one i hope anyone who reads this review will avoid.

Review title: Let's use artistic license as an excuse to completely falsify the event
Review_body:
Really? Another movie about the 1996 Everest tragedy? Oh, and this time we will use artistic license to completely misrepresent characters, twist facts, deny real heroes their recognition and generally throw random crap at the audience. With the 15 second attention spans of today, it is disgusting that a segment of the population will be in awe of this banal worthless attempt. I was at the edge of my seat as the helicopter clipped the snow bank (yeah, not really, only complete idiots would have bought into that).
Next time, change the name of mountain, the characters and everything else and see if you can sell such an insulting script to people who actually have a 3 digit IQ.
Dr. Weathers could not have possibly given consent to this feeble attempt of mis-represented drama and tragedy where the man who risked his life to rescue him was not even mentioned by title or accurate portrayal.
The only reason for a couple of stars is that there are fleeting moments of scenery that remind me of the mountains and their majesty.

I went to see the movie with high expectations because of the cast & came out with big wow in my mouth.Other than the cast the visual of the movie affected me very much.every scene is stunning,it made to feel i was in mountain because of breathless scenes. everyone acted very well didn't use any cliché bonding friendship in the end or any other dramas they stick to their role & done a fine job i knew Jake & josh they wont disappoint me but Jason Clarke proved that he is also dependable actor with his performance.This movie is in every way to deserve an Oscar.

Just to correct Adarsh Bohra's review on here "Another Classic from Jake Gyllenhall", where he incorrectly states " The fact that some engaging, friendly Aussies are front and center as the main tour organizers and guides may account for a good deal of the films immediate accessibility; they're the competent, reassuring type you'd feel good entrusting yourself to on such an expedition." The main tour organizers, principally Rob Hall (played by Jason Clarke), are in fact New Zealanders. Hall's wife Jan Arnold (Keira Knightley) who he communicates with via satellite phone, is a New Zealand academic, at the time of the disaster teaching Sociology at my alma mater, the University of Canterbury, Christchurch, New Zealand. Christchurch, like Nepal has sadly been devastated by an earthquake in recent years, with 80% of the city centre destroyed.New Zealand has close links with Nepal since the first conquest of Everest in 1953 by New Zealander Edmund Hillary and Nepalese Sherpa Tenzing Norgay. Many climbing parties continue to be lead by Kiwis just as Rob Hall's in the movie. Edmund Hillary preferred to be remembered for the many schools and hospitals he built in Nepal. He regretted the commercialisation of Everest climbing and the volumes of rubbish left on the mountain.
Never understood why this wasn't at the Oscars. Have seen this picture already four times and keeps me at the edge of my seat everytime.

Review title: The movie is about the true story that took place in 1996, about some people who tried to climb to the top of Everest.
Review_body: WARNING:Spoiler Alert!!!This was a fine and entertaining film. There is a few things that i did not liked, but they do not really matter. There is some characters I really liked and did not wanted to die( Jake Gyllenhaal's character, John Hawkes's character and Jason Clarke's character). It did not knew the real story, so the end was a surprise for me. It's a pretty sad movie, which was unexpected and the only main character who survived was the worst one (Josh Brolin's character). It is a good movie. It made my cry and it totally deserves 7/10. The casting is done well. I, my friends and my family enjoyed the movie. In one sentence: very good movie, but "The Martian" was way better.

Ever since I found out that there is going to be a movie about 1996 disaster, I was thrilled. I had just read "Into thin air" by J. Krakauer, one of the survivors, and I was so moved by it, that I wanted to learn something more. And when I read that this movie won't be entirely based on this book, I was even happier because it meant new perspective. I have to say - Jason Clarke was the perfect choice. I didn't know him before, I had seen only "Zero Dark Thirty", but that was it. At first I actually hoped, that Jake Gyllenhaal will have a bigger role, just because I knew what to expect from him. But Jason really shined as Rob and his and Keira's conversations touched me. It was beautifully filmed, the sound effects were fantastic, and, since I had read the book, I had almost no problem to identify the characters. The only thing that I wanted to change was that I wanted to know more about others as well. Rob was the only one I actually cared about, and I don't think that was only my problem - it's just that the others didn't capture my attention.Overall it was a beautiful movie, but I don't think that 3D is necessary.

I watched this movie going in thinking that I was going to see a heroic and nail-biting story about some climbers making it back down the highest mountain in the world during a storm. Now, I might have had high expectations, but that doesn't excuse how bad the story of this movie was. Now, I realize that it is a true story, but I don't understand why they made it a movie. Rob, (a character) for example. The whole movie was building him up, seeing his relationship with his wife, the other climbers, and the mountain. You think, "This guy will lead everyone to safety!". They even show him instructing the other climbers, which, from the start, usually tells you that they know what they are doing. But, some of the last scenes he is in, shows him running out of oxygen, barely able to talk. Then they let him talk to his wife to help motivate him. They talk for a bit, say they love each other, then they stop. He then dies. Its not a heroic death either, not trying to disrespect him, may he rest in peace, but from a storytelling point of view its just so sudden. Why get you emotionally attached to this character if they die without much of a fight? They didn't make it seems like he was going to die, he seemed OK. Multiple others die as well, such as a guy, Doug I think, who planted a flag for elementary school kids, to help motivate them to follow their dreams, he died by falling off the edge, presumably so rob wouldn't have to risk his life to come back for him. He was OK, we learned his motives, got somewhat attached, then felt sad for his death. And the whole story as a whole is bad. They climb up, have problems, make it, then climb down. Like 4 people died on the way down, and then it ends. I had no idea who was who on the way down, with the masks, and the snow, it was just hard to tell. This make me wonder, "Wait, who just died? Wait did that one guys make it?" Overall, it's a pretty nice movie, but with a bad plot. Visuals are AMAZING, tensions are high, and it took risks. But the plot was boring. You only get attached to a couple characters, and it reached climax, falling action, but no resolution.

Review title: This is a DRAMA movie not an ACTION movie, people!
Review_body: A lot of the reviewers here who have voted low on this movie were expecting an ACTION movie. Well, sorry folks. Go and watch some trashy JJ Abrams or Michael Bay rubbish if you want that. This movie is actually a DRAMA. Why is it a drama? Because it is based on TRUE EVENTS. And that is where it leaves ACTION and gets into DOCUMENTARY. And this is where this movie SUCCEEDS.It does not go all "Hollywood" on the script and add in "action" scenes to appease the popcorn eating morons that can't comprehend anything more than flashing lights, bangs and sirens. It does not even have a "good guy" and a "bad guy." It has to be ACCURATE otherwise it can only claim to be "based on true events" instead of being "a true story." So shut up idiots who said this movie was "boring" or "had no action" etc etc etc. YOU people are boring and your attention spans are that of children. Having said that, the movie is well made. There are big names in it. The only thing that annoyed me slightly is that lead character is played by an Australian and makes absolutely ZERO effort at sounding like a New Zealander which he is supposed to be. It makes me wonder if that was intentional. Imagine this: some "true-blue" New Zealander in the main role would lose most of the audience with his unintelligible accent, due to their horrendous treatment of vowels, "the ear is thoon ... and the weether is bed." (This is the very reason New Zealanders can't be understood by the rest of the English-speaking world.) SO, I get it. At least Australian vowels are more in keeping with the rest of the world. On the other hand Keira Knightly and Emily Watson's New Zealand accents were almost dead on - as busted as that accent is. Good effort, ladies. I cringed in all the right places. The story was well executed. The ending was quite touching. Knowing that this is an unembellished telling of true events it makes it even more emotional. My hat goes off to this great mountaineer and New Zealander (sorry, won't fall into that kitschy, cutesy thing of calling a New Zealander a "Kiwi.")

This movie was extremely intense. The point was to convey what these particular people went through and how dramatic/ dangerous everything was.100% hit the nail on the head. I'm doing my best to not mention anything in particular but so many moments were leaving me on the edge of my seat and biting my nails. Small introduction story for the main character and the other characters had their small explanation as to why they were there but it's wasn't just about digging in to who they were, but more into what they did and went through. The depiction of how certain events happened was done so well you can't help but to squirm a little bit from the intensity. It ends up being quite the emotional roller-coaster and it a must to see it with a big TV and surround sound if you couldn't see it in the theater. Excellent movie.

I was the only one interested in watching this yet at the end they all joined me in being bored. Interesting premise but somehow it managed to turn out boring, how? I don't know. Anyways the best but definitely could have been worse.

I feel like the movie insults the viewer's intelligence with the fact that the whole situation started when the Main Guide(Big Man Sherpa) decided to risk his life and implicitly risked his unborn daughter growing up without a father just because a Mailman(a customer who wanted to reach the top of the mountain) convinced him to go the extra mile and reach the top albeit not being aware of the dangers he was already in and refused to turn back. To make matters worse, the movie is based on a true story? I'm not sure how much of it is true, the main guide's body is still on the mountain, I'm not surprised since he was taking advice from his customers rather then doing his job and ending up killing both himself and the mailman. This is the true story the guys behind the movie chose to turn into a picture? Why? The acting was good.

I went in without reading any reviews on this. I didn't know, until the end, this was a true story. Sad to say. These brave men and women who climbed this beast are heroes on my book. Such and unfriendly mountain with so many obstacles. Weather, cold, snow, storms, wind, avalanche, ice, lack of oxygen, to name but a few. A 1 acting by all. My favorite character is Jake. He fit the role well. Most scary part was the helicopter trying to land and then when it took off I thought it was going to crash. The makeup was better than Black Mass (lol) but serious to make the nose look like it did was an awesome job. I think the category of makeup should go to this movie.

Review title: Probably the most accurate but least compelling account
Review_body: The best audience for this movie may be people not familiar with the various and varying accounts of the 1996 expeditions. But the cinematography gives you a true feel of the riskiness of the environment: knife edge cornices, 2 foot trails with 5,000 foot drops, the seemingly endless ascent. Having read most of those aforementioned accounts, the movie makes only brief exposition of the debated critical errors. Some are totally ignored. I was much more emotional reading the accounts. Feeling the gut-wrenching nature of the life and death decision made when an ascent or descent goes wrong. I didn't get that feeling with this movie.But if you don't want to get into a debate over who made the most mistakes (Boukreev vs. Hall. vs. Fischer vs. Ang Dorje, etc.), it's a very good accounting of the events from the perspective of the Adventure Consultants' camp.
How can this movie paint this man as a coward?The idea that being a hero at that altitude and not suffer your own death is just insane,

First of all, if you don't see the film in IMAX 3D, you will not get the same feeling you get when watching this film that I did. The main issue with the movie lies in the first act because the problem is the entire first act. The movie is in rapid fire for the first 30-45 minutes. There is limited time for character introduction and the film seems rushed. By the 15 minute mark, they are practically already climbing the mountain and this is something that shouldn't have happened until the second act. There are times where a character's name is said and you really can't remember which one they are due to the lack of introduction. However, come time for the second act and things start to come back to the light. The intensity rises and you start to care for the characters more than you did before. It becomes an emotional thriller that will have you on the edge of your seat. It creates a realistic environment (complimented by the IMAX 3D) that immerses you in the film. The acting is fantastic and if I were a part of the Academy I would attempt to give Josh Brolin a supporting actor nomination, but of course, that won't happen. In conclusion, once the first act is in the past, the film regains its footing and becomes a great film that leaves you scratching you head wondering, "how did they film that?" To be honest, going on I was unaware that this was actually a true story. It makes the movie more emotional and all the more thrilling,I highly recommend the film.

Review title: thrilling and emotional but never could summit
Review_body: First of all, bravo on the cinematography. This film has some of the best visuals i have ever seen on film and it really makes you feel like you are 29.029 feet up touching the highest point on earth. The IMAX experience was unlike anything i have ever seen. I was almost expecting to feel the cold wind in my seat as the group struggled for survival after their expedition goes very wrong. I would not be surprised if this film wins an Oscar for best cinematography. it was really that good. The characters were a bit underdeveloped i thought with an exception of Jason Clarke and Josh Brolin who were the two standout performances for me. Sam Worthington was exceptional as well but with limited screen time. Jake Gyllenhaal was the biggest waste of a character since as far as i can remember. you knew his fate from the very first time you saw him and he was extremely under utilized. after all the main character was the mountain itself which got the most screen time. (not necessarily a bad thing)I did not look up the story until after watching the movie because i didn't want anything ruined and while watching this movie i found it to be rather slow in getting the momentum going. Its really only the last 30-45 minutes of the movie where things get pretty intense. I was expecting Jason Clarke and Jake Gyllenhaal to team up and combine leadership skills and resources and fight back down the mountain but that does not happen at all. However the filmmakers did not stray too far from the actual story so i can't really knock the film for that as it is probably the most realistic portrayal of a disaster/survival story since "The Impossible" and some of the main characters deaths are pretty emotional. overall it was a very enjoyable theater experience and i look forward to watching the bonus features on the blu ray a few months from now and seeing how this film was shot because it was absolutely stunning. 6.5/10

The movie is a nice combination of drama, emotions and bravery.What makes the movie even more interesting is that it is based on actual events from 1996. You do not have to be a mountaineer or adventure junkie to appreciate the movie. The gripping storyline keeps you hooked all throughout.The magnificence of Mount Everest is evident in the movie, which not only makes you realize - how extremely difficult it is to conquer the peak, but also it helps us appreciate a mountaineer's true grit, courage and physical endurance.Great Star cast, Impressive Photography and Cinematography and Locations. All in all - Amazing movie experience!

Review title: Everest definitely dares you to imagine what it must be like to be at the top of the world with everything around going horribly, horribly wrong.
Review_body: 1996 - The deadliest year (19 fatalities) ever on Mount Everest during a trek, chronicled by writer Jon Krakaeur in "Into Thin Air". With 1 fatality for every four successful hikes to the summit, what does it take for one to dare into Mount Everest's "death zone". Man is it simple named that way? With low-oxygen and harsh and rapidly changing weather conditions, Director Baltasar Komakur provides us the ultimate experience and this is the closest most of us viewers are ever going to get to scaling the world's highest peak.Rob (Jason Clarke) is the leader of an expedition guiding company called Adventure Consultants, specializing in commercial mountain climbing of Mount Everest. He leads eight of his clients to the summit. The director gives the viewers' time to acclimate to the expedition group and the dangers involved, while the cast acclimate to the altitude and oxygen deprivation.The entire cast and crew have done an excellent job in crafting and bringing to life this real-life disaster with an emotional consistency as well. Everest definitely dares you to imagine what it must be like to be at the top of the world with everything around going horribly, horribly wrong. With the fates of the different climbers unsure, Everest is nail- biting tense. But as the true consequences of the disaster becomes clear, that tension turns into grim sadness amid frozen corpses.Everest boasts of a handful of spectacular shots that show how small the climbers are against the awe and majesty of Everest (definitely watch in IMAX if you can). Those shots are relatively scarce and one of the most effective uses of IMAX is when Beck slips while trying to cross a terrifyingly deep chasm over a wobbly ladder. Maybe if we experienced less of the climber's suffering and more of the mountain's majesty, their adventure would have been more inspiring.While there are moments where the towering peak is overshadowed by the human dram, the viewers can forgive them in favor of the compelling experience of ascent and descent to the summit which is heaven for a moment and hell the next.

Everest is one of the few movies of this year that I had waited a while for and it was well worth the wait.It takes multiple accounts of what happened on the top of Everest and points towards the closest accurate account we are ever going to get other than the IMAX documentary filled at the time of the tragedy.Listening to Rob Hall (played by Jason Clarke) speak to his wife while stranded on the mountain was epic. Word for word what he said when he said goodbye to Jan replayed for audiences with Jan Arnold Halls approval.This is not an easy movie to watch and it shouldn't be. People died on that mountain. Some to never return home to their families and to never be discovered.What makes this movie epic is the amount of time the actual cast and crew spent at base camp acclimating and preparing to file this rigorous film. Their dedication showed in every frame.The story of Rob Hall and those with him on that mountain have helped change how Everest is approached. Those that were lucky enough to make it off that mountain are lucky to be alive.Beck Weathers was an amateur climber with an extremely worthy resume but lost his hands and nose in this climb due to the story and the number of people in that mountain that year.Jon Krakauer's story of a journalist making it to the top of the world and back and the journey of others who risked it all and more but this movie shows the missing information from his book Into Thin Air by adding in accounts from Beck Weathers, Anatoli Boukreev and another survivor who have since written about the disaster and this is to Krakauer's benefit. Krakauer leaves much to be desired in his account by taking potshots at other climbers and this account clears things and shows that disasters happen even when you plan.Congrats to an amazing cast and crew on putting together a brilliant story of a tragedy that needed to be told.I hope the families of those left behind are proud of this film as no one is made to be the villain. They are all hero's and fighters.Beautifully made. See it as soon as possible.

Review title: Climbing Everest - Removed from my Bucket List
Review_body: My summary above is actually just a joke. I will never even attempt an activity where you have a 25% chance of losing your life! Since the film is based on true events, I don't want to be too critical and harsh on the characters that lost their lives in this tragedy, but clearly instructions were ignored (Leave the summit by 14:00) and some basic precautions (oxygen tanks) seemed to have been completely missed. With all due respect, many of the people that died in this tragedy made the wrong decisions, an it cost them dearly. Many decisions were selfish in my opinion. Many did this because of their ego or wanting to prove something to themselves or their families etc. When the journalist asked why people want to reach the summit, none of the answers were really convincing to me.What I liked about this film is obviously the cinematography and some solid acting. It also seems to follow the actual events quite closely. It did make me think much further than only Everest. Many of us are faced daily with decisions. Some are small and some are life changing. How we react to these challenges can change our lives forever. This has clearly been illustrated and confirmed in Everest.I see that people mention that the first hour of the movie was boring. I actually really enjoyed to see what work and effort actually go into an expedition to the summit. It was really insightful. I do however now firmly believe that Everest has been conquered and I don't understand how people still want to take the risk to go up there.

Review title: Taller tales have been better told for shorter mountains
Review_body: Everest is not a bad movie, but it isn't a pretty one either, it's pretty bad! especially for anyone who has viewed mountaineering and/or survival themed movies before. Cinematography: The cinematography is certainly good. Some panoramic scenes are breathtaking and successfully convey the awesomeness of the task that is scaling the Everest.Music score: I can't recall now if the movie even has an original music score or any music at all. A rather odd exception for a movie that is bound to have elements of suspense and intense human drama.Casting: There are some big names in the cast, who have been assigned small parts and the lead roles given to relative and complete unknowns. The audience has an obvious expectation of the significance of a character based on the reputation of the actor playing that part. Now, big names are sometimes used to play characters that die early and unexpectedly to put the reassured audience in a state of shock and real sense of danger about the remaining characters. However, Everest employs no such ploy. The casting is just plain nonsensical.Character development: Rarely have I seen a movie that does a worse job of character development than Everest. There is a lot of time spent on absolutely irrelevant small-talk, boring background description, prosaic emotional dialogues and for so many characters. At the end of this we are left with one dimensional characters. There isn't a single character, including the protagonist (whoever that is?) that is even two dimensional. It is difficult to impossible to relate or care about any of the characters. One could not care less if a character went up the mountain, or down, or just round and round. It felt weird to be so enormously apathetic about any character falling in or out of peril on the slopes.Acting: I suppose some of the bigger actors tried to do the best they could with the small parts and insipid dialogues, but the actors in the leading parts failed to deliver. The portrayal was dead-pan throughout.Direction, Script-writer: The only thing that could compare to the everest in this movie is the colossal failure of the director and the script-writer. A mediocre school-boy writing and presenting his first essay ever in school would do about the same as these two. A directionless rambling of random excerpts from a book about the story. When you watch how some directors and script-writers can get a character under your skin in a few minutes you realize just how bad a job was done in this movie.Movie is art ... not a tax-return form: One can understand that the director wanted to be true to the actual story to the letter, with no dramatization, with an assumption that the grandiose setting, that is the Everest, would naturally and automatically impress itself upon the mind of the audience. Unfortunately (or fortunately) the audience cannot implicitly feel the bone chilling winds, or the asphyxiating low oxygen air, or acrophobia, or fatigue sitting in their cushioned seats. They need to be shown these things visually, or through the condition of characters they have been made to care about conveyed through dialog or action. However, Everest director seems to forget these very fundamentals of movie making.Conclusion: Go see 'Touching the void' instead of this movie and if you have already seen 'Touching the void', then go see it again and it will surely be more suspenseful, entertaining, and rewarding than watching Everest.

Review title: Thoroughly Tear Jerking...Best Film I've seen in a long time
Review_body: This is a beautiful but harrowing film,which will have you on the edge of your seat the entire time! I felt sick with worry and cried my eyes out. The acting in the film is fantastic and really had you believing the story. I mean through the entire film it was like I was there rooting for the characters and there families. I was hiding behind a pillow one minute and screaming at the television the next! This is the sort of film that really helps to give you perspective. In my opinion the actors really make you believe that they are the people that this happened to in real life. Watch it! You will come away speechless! But in a good way! 😃

Review title: Perhaps a version of 1996 Everest tragedy. Good movie
Review_body: This film is based on 1996 Mount Everest disaster. It doesn't completely cover it, and tells the story of two main expedition teams who got involved in it. It can't be said to be a "true story". It can't be said to be a filmed inspired from the tragedy. It is like something that goes in between these two. Perhaps we can say it does not cover the tragedy completely but do give us the feeling – the feeling of grief and you may be engulfed in that grief cloud for a couple of days. In the initial parts, we get to see some parts of Nepal (other than the ice-capped Himalayas) but then we would get too involved in getting to know the characters that we would literally pay no attention to it. Also once we get to see the majestic mountains, new characters again get into picture, as we keep registering in our brains as to who is who, we totally forget the mountains. There aren't many shots showing the natural beauty around or any shot (long enough,) for us to gape at the beauty of the majestic mountains. But once the real mountaineering begins, one can't help but appreciate the way it has been filmed, Simply awesome. Action scenes are good, and there is no exaggeration. There is a scene where Beck Weathers falls off a ladder. This gives a small glance as to how things can go wrong. However, just the walking pace of the climbers is enough to let the audience know what the mountain can do to you. Once the descent starts, the story becomes mostly about Rob Hall (or Adventure Consultants). The other characters could have also been portrayed a bit more like in the beginning of the movie where we get a peek onto why each one is planning to summit and also an introduction to Weathers family. Same could have been done in the end too and also some thing of the Mountain Madness clients. You can't fit everything into 2 hours, I guess. When the disaster strikes, you do get a feeling that you are up there grasping for breath. Some scenes do get us into questioning some of the decisions taken by the characters, but then its all explained in the beginning, "Its not called the Death Zone for nothing". If you feel grief stricken and it doesn't go away after a few days, just watch the movie again. The second time you would be drawing your attention towards other things, like South Col, Balcony, Hillary Step and of course, who is who under their masks (it's a tough job. I guess they removed their masks at summit just to show us who is who!!). Again, if you are interested you can google on 1996 Everest Disaster and find out that the whole thing hasn't gotten into the movie. Also, reading Jon Krakauer's Into Thin Air. But if you are reading it, then make sure you read Anatoli Boukreev's The Climb and you get to see the whole thing from another angle. Whatever we research on, we will never be able to know for sure what all happened on that fateful day. So its best to think of it as a version of the 1996 Everest tragedy and try to enjoy it as just another movie.
This movie is just made for big screens or a night with the family so see it. I think it is worth it.

Everest : For one thing about the movie is sure - that it is unjust. I had been fascinated by the incident ever since I first read about it and was eagerly awaiting the movie. Although, Baltasar Kormakur made a very brave attempt, the movie seems only inspired by the book 'Into Thin Air' by Jon Krakauer and it completely forgets to honour the exceptional mountaineer and the sole hero of the incident, Anatoli Boukreev. If you really feel awed by the story, I would suggest you read the books 'Into Thin Air' by Krakauer and 'The Climb' by Boukreev himself; and then make up your opinion, for such superhuman feats are rarely heard of. If you are watching it for simple entertainment, just go ahead..!!

The catch line on the movie poster says "Never Let Go" and right at the bottom, based on incredible true story. Never let go of what precisely? Doug, Harold, Rob Hall, Scott, all let go of themselves. The Sherpas sent to rescue Rob Hall turned back at the earliest sign of a storm and his buddy at base camp literally just say, OK. and honestly, i don't know how incredible a story is when more than half the climbers end up dead? For the dead climber's sake, i seriously hope that what was shown in the movie did not accurately reflect the true event, because, most, if not all of the dead climbers wasn't killed because of the storm, they're dead because they're unbearably stupid. Take Scott for example, being a guide, he must have been to the top more than once. What's the point of wasting your life just to be up there again? Rob being an experienced guide should know better than to allow a weak climber already low on oxygen to make summit way PAST the turnaround time! and it didn't take much effort to persuade him either. This movie is so disturbing and depressing. What's the point in making a movie where everyone end up dead? While i understand this is based on true events where people actually died, i feel the writer shouldn't have made it into such a morally depleting movie. Writer should at least try to make someone a hero. If you're thinking of scaling the Everest, or any mountain really, DO NOT WATCH THIS MOVIE. Hell, you might even retire from climbing after watching this movie.

Everest is based on the story of the 1996 expedition to climb Mount Everest gone wrong, causing several casualties.The first hour of the movie, which should have set up the story as well as a good foundation of characters' background, doesn't do any of that. It mostly consists of airport and travel scenes, goodbyes, and mini dialogues about previous mountain experiences. All of that ends up to be a very boring and shallow first part of the movie, which thus lacks intensity. This is especially important to know, because, in the second half. When things become tragic, the viewer does not feel an emotional attachment to the characters, because he barely knows them.Within that, the characters are extremely flat and none of the actors' performances stand out. For example, Jake Gyllenhaal's part could have been played by anybody else. Having stars in the movie did not contribute to its quality, only to its notoriety.In the second part, things start to go downhill (storms, avalanches, lack of equipment resulting in deaths, etc.) and the movie changes pace. In some sequences, the movie gets more intense, like the helicopter rescue and the husband and wife farewell over the phone. However, the movie doesn't make the step from telling a very dramatic story to emotionally involving the viewer in it.That being said, the whole movie is supported by the spectacular Everest landscaping. 6 out of 10.

Review title: Worth watching but could have been lots better
Review_body: I think the main problem with this movie is a loose focus. It seems like they tried to make a disaster, drama and documentary stories at the same time but failed to develop any of that properly. But the good things first: stunning scenery, overall tension and a few really great scenes make this movie worth watching without a doubt. It is just somehow not working as a single piece. With a fast start you expect some eventful action to follow but there's nothing like that. The characters developing is limited to a couple of sentences excluding Rob Hall and Beck Weathers what makes others a little more than forgettable 'guys who die first'. For some reason, Scott Fisher, being a smart capable mountaineer is shown as a careless hippie-like person, Anatoli Boukreev as a cliché tough Russian playing garmon in a tent, Beck Weathers as a hardly-realistic guy from Texas. But it doesn't matter anyways as when the masks put on it's really hard to follow who is who and and their position on the mountain, especially on descending. The whole day of May 11 is clumsy and hardly could be learned from the movie, on the summit the story switches to Rob completely and gets distractingly touchy-feely then slowly turning into the aftermath. The drama feels a bit out of place when other participants dying with little or no attention. I was disappointed. The most vivid scene of the movie turned out to be shown in the trailer (crevasse ladder). Another Beck Weathers scene was really powerful too, but otherwise I didn't feel the pressure of surviving, the height itself (the stormy clouds could be seen from 2000 as well), an incredible effort to even try to step on that track.Andre Bredenkamp writes about Everest climb: "You get completely disorientated. I had to keep reminding myself I was climbing a mountain. Every step of the way I had to try to motivate myself. At that altitude I took at least 10 to 15 breaths each time I moved one foot."So if you really want to feel the height I would rather recommend to read the books about that night as this movie failed to show it properly.

Review title: yet another example of over-exaggerated Western Heroism
Review_body: Who put those ropes in? Who put the ladders across the ice-fall? Who put up those tents they're climbing into? Who carried the oxygen? Who carried the food they're now eating? The Sherpas do that work and that is never shown. The Sherpas did a huge amount of work on this expedition and they were heavily involved in the rescue. There were also Sherpas killed so I think it's yet another example of them being left out of the story, yet another example of over-exaggerated Western Heroism.
Watched this movie recently in TV. Its really good. Movie really replicated the accident. Cinematography looks very natural. Its make us to feel in Himalayas.

I absolutely loved this movie!! I was a bit circumspect after reading some negative comments. After finishing the movie, I was thinking these people need to be banned. The direction, cinematography and acting were all top class. Best thing I loved about it was that I felt like I knew every character, I was feeling what they were going through! Goes to show how the characters were represented and the story telling. Jason Clarke was the highlight of the movie, he was great in every scene. Only disappointment for me was the lack of use of Jake Gyllenhaal, thought he could have been given more screen space. Josh Brolin and all other actors did a good job too. I highly recommended this movie if you like this genre!

I personally think it was pretty impressive movie. Story line was beautifully written from the character's background to their state at Base Camp. I won't lie it made me sentimental at a point. Those breathtaking scenes were amazing. Everything has its flaw like wise things i found odd was Scott Fischer's story. I feel different for the guy. It was like he came, he died. No inside story. That guy deserved better story or something. And how did Beck happen to be alive its mystery but felt good after he came back. I was hoping Rob would come back which he never did. Which kinda made me sad. I'm from Nepal that may have boosted my review to positive or not but i would definitely recommend to anyone who loves adventures (trekking, hiking etc).

Review title: "Never Let Go" - It does not stay with you
Review_body: Okay, so Everest is a really simple story. This group, that group, all want to go the summit of Everest, with the proclamation: I have made it! But is this true story film, good enough? Yes...and no.This film stars Jason Clarke as Robb Hall, Jake Gyllenhaal as Scott Fisher, Josh Brolin as Beck Weathers, and many others. Yes, this film is star studded. And that is not bad, as the film did not suffer from their presences. Everybody played their part, and good. It has nice visuals, great sound design, dazzling cinematography, and at times rouses tension. But it is not tactful enough to make that tension prominent, instead the scene just passes, and another comes up. When the film wanted me to care to for a character, I just wanted to see some snow action; and this being a true story - it having happened to people, who are now dead - I think I should have felt sympathy. But I couldn't. Everest is disjointed in its narrative, containing some clichés, which could've have been left out, that I just could not care. It had its pacing issues. At points the film is moving slow, then suddenly - whoop! - action, then back to slow. I think for films like this - based on true story - one should read the book to really get to grip with the story. But, no. This is a movie, not a book. The book does not matter here, and I'm reviewing the film as it was presented. And for a film based on a book about a true incident, it was okay.I had fun with Everest, but in the end I just left the cinema of another movie. It does not stick with me, leaving an impression. Most probably IMAX was a better 'experience', but eh. It was okay, and that's all. And now the director is working on a film named Reykjavik. I wonder how that will play out...

Just came back from the cinema. Experienced "Everest" in 3D. The best 3D experience since "Avatar".The movie was fantastic. A movie that traps you in the experience of the characters. Last time I felt that was while watching David Lynch's "Lost Highway" at the cinema.Everything about this movie is great. The acting, visuals, sounds, music, story, story, story. As the movie ended, I realized that half an hour had passed while I was holding my breath.This is the one film to experience in 3D and on a large screen. And there were no clichés. Just perfect.

Firstly before this movie I held mountains in no special regard at all, Secondly I was not really looking forward to the movie. I watched this movie with my girlfriend and was left spell bound by Mount Everest so much so I instantly went to research the 8000m peaks of the world as the film finished. Beautifully and brilliantly acted what more could you want from a movie. The power of Everest was amazingly captured by the cameraman and the exertion on the climbers was apparent in the actors too. One of the funny things is when the movie ended I found myself watching a documentary about the 1996 everest disaster and found the survivors to be just like the actors portraying them in the movie especially Beck weathers. I would highly recommend this movie to all.

Review title: If you love mountains or adventure, watch it.
Review_body: Mountains share a one-sided relationship with mountaineers. They do not necessarily give the love back. Mountains behave to their will, live by its own and retain their self-composure indifferent to the time and living beings in its proximity. That is why climbers can reach the summit but not win the mountain. They never can. If a mountain is won, it no longer remains a mountain. It reduces to a pile of rocks.The film Everest understands well the fundamentally free nature of mountains. It could be because the film presents a real-life case that naturally observes this fact. But also because film makers made an effort to understand and accept it. Everest is not a tale of exaggerated heroism. Although the story has a lot of moments when characters could go out-of-the-way to save other troupe members, or demonstrate few acrobatics on snow. Fortunately, they do not. The film is also light on drama, saving some portion around the dying Rob.The 120 minute adventure-thriller keeps you on the edge of your seat with many breath taking shots of Great Himalayas. I will not include it however in any special camera-work as one only needs a helicopter to fly around for these shots. The aesthetics were ready made since 450 million years back when the Himalayas were born. Rather the real skills on camera are demonstrated in climbing shots framing the climbing trails in an absolutely inspirational manner. And the camera just fires up during the hail storm creating the needed velocity and ferociousness.A Climbing Scene Viewers would enjoy the Everest travelogue, looking at the response of families as they see-off their kin to most dangerous of expeditions, how people unite at the Everest base camp, how expedition is managed by professional staff, the churning climb-up, bewitching summit clash and the flustering walk back to the lower camps. The story is compact, and keeps a solid pace. This simultaneously means film never enters the cervices, keeping a strong foot on the broad, top edge.Certainly no points are scored by the film on focusing at the psychology of mountaineers, and sadly neither on the finer aspects of climbing as a skill and art. There is a bit of a mountaineer's mental process in the conversation when Beck tells Doug, he is surrounded by a sort of 'depression' at home, and it disappears when he climbs. And in the same follow-up they talk about suffering during the climb, and how it would end upon reaching back home. It is a common cycle for climbers, and in fact everyone who traverse the wild, to look upon their trail like madmen until it happens, then suffer its consequences, finally craving for the home they explicitly abhorred at the start. Other than this insight, audience would no where feel the passion, grit and conditions that prepare those who engage in high altitude climbs. They'll also have no clue on the technical attributes of trails, ropes, hooks, weather forecast and equipment. I had no doubt that such a direction had made the film an Adventure Classic.If you love mountains, like the wild- go watch Everest.

Review title: I can't add anything to what has been said except...
Review_body: I didn't read IMDb.com carefully (shameless plug) and thought Everest was going to be a documentary. I was pleasantly surprised to find that it was more of a docudrama based on real events.I often choose which movies to view based on the appropriateness of the language used, with the rationale that if I don't speak that way and no one in my home should, why should I pay for the same? I can think of dozens of other films I've seen that were ruined by inserting swear words where they seemed out of place. I applaud the movie Everest for being an intense adventure movie that used virtually no objectionable language--at least that I can remember. The lack of offensive language was incredibly refreshing.The footage and drama were in this movie were riveting. I marveled that when the climbers were having such a hard time in some scenes shot from above, how the photographers were able to record such shots. They must have been staged on other mountains, but they looked realistic to me.

I'm really disappointed with reviews on IMDb it is suppose to be a page where people can make a decision on watching a movie or not, especially when these days an IMAX ticket cost almost 20 bucks, based on early review I went to watch this movie and here is my review. The best part in the movie was the trailers in the beginning, really!!! OK let me at least try to give this movie a somewhat favored review, first 15 minutes were engaging because the director shows parts of Nepal and how that part of the world is different than western world. The star- cast of this movie is the biggest bait for movie goers, assuming so many good actors the movie has to be good, it has to have some screenplay, some thrill, some comedy and there was None! Those who are interested in the story it would be enough to read the wikipedia page about the real disaster this movie isn't worth a DVD view.And please people leave a fair review and fair ratings of the movies, otherwise the whole purpose of this website is zero.

Review title: Good to Watch but Expected more
Review_body:
Stunning Scenery and awesome mountain scene makes it worth to watch.If I could watch it in the 3D would have been make it super awesome.Characters more or less justify themselves.
 One big mistake, the movie uses a bollywood song which released on 2001 but the story in movie was of 1996. I think the storytelling could be better in this movie.

Review title: My experience with this the movie.
Review_body: Spoilers is advised, stop reading after this message!Seeing the trailer to "Everest" was great, knowing about it being a thrilling survival movie that's based on a true story, it can get people interested. But coming out of the movie theater, i wasn't too impressed. The story was way too simple, get up the mountain and don't die. Not a lot of the characters had a real reason to go up the tallest and most dangerous mountain in the world, either just to be another mountain they climb or to get away from family, because the are miserable. The main himself knows that he's going to have a daughter, so what does he do...goes on a suicide mission to be in the newspaper. When it comes to characters, the writers of this movie, could have gone deep into these characters to show the audience the real reason why they're doing this, but no hand wave it away and then kill almost all of them. This movie lacks music, the movie "Argo" was based on a true story and it had more amazing kinds of music. Where in this movie I just hear snow or tragic music, but i get the idea, some people died, but not through the whole movie. My biggest complaint about this movie, the camera continues to shape, making me seasick sometimes. But once that camera stops moving; what a relief that is to just appreciate the settings in the movie. My favorite element to this movie is the setting; the view on the top of Everest was unbelievable with just that moment of silents. The movie "Everest" to me is a slightly above average movie that is a movie to see at least one time.

hyped to heavens this movie is not too good.. u can easily predict what can happen in the next scene. its just mediocre.i anticipated a great deal about the scenes in the movie. but this movie is just disappointing.. the story is so predictable... hyped to heavens this movie is not too good.. u can easily predict what can happen in the next scene. its just mediocre.i anticipated a great deal about the scenes in the movie. but this movie is just disappointing.. the story is so predictable... hyped to heavens this movie is not too good.. u can easily predict what can happen in the next scene. its just mediocre.i anticipated a great deal about the scenes in the movie. but this movie is just disappointing.. the story is so predictable...

more than 100000 votes , 7\10 rate , 64 Metascore , Jake Gyllenhaal and Kiera Knightley , All this encouraged me to watch the movie . I started the movie and I was so excited but I really got disappointed , here is why : The movie is based on true story in 1996 about climbers who want to reach the top of Everest Mt which is really dangerous , you could die there! , each one of the climbers paid 65 thousands dollars to do this ! and not all of them are reach ! , one of them left his pregnant wife of their first baby ! and the other is a poor mailman ! Adventure :there's no adventure in the movie , because at the start of the movie they tell you that all of the climbers will reach and no one of them will die !!! and the first hour of the movie is about reaching to the top of Everest , why did they let the watcher know this ! I really have no F***ing idea ! Drama : why would I have sympathy for stupid people who paid 65000 thousands dollars to do something dangerous , while they could do so many better things with the money for themselves and for the world ?! why would I have a sympathy for a wife who married a stupid husband who left her while she's pregnant for her first time ! , I really don't give a sh*t about them ,simply they're an a**holes.what's the point ? really , why do you tell me a story like this !? why do you make a movie about this story ? why did you pay 55 millions dollars for this ! ... there's a lot of suffering in this world , people die because they can't find water , food or medicine , women get raped by ISIS , people die because of their color or religion ...etc! go and open any history book and you will find a lot of suffering and a real drama stories , (don't make another movie about holocaust , enough!) instead of this you tell me a story about bunch of American di*ks who waste their money ! come on ...the music and the cinematography , the directing and the acting was good , but they don't matter because the story sucks.
I thought after Vertical Limit no one would make a ridiculous unconvincing movie about big mountains, but here we are. Sure, a better story than VL, but poorly told and executed.

Everest is an overall good movie, based on a true story, with convincing acting, a good pace and some beautiful mountain shots. I strongly recommend to see it on the biggest scrren possible.If you are looking for another typical boring disaster movie this is not for you, otherwise see it, you won't be disappointed.

Review title: Everest is as de facto" as blockbuster can be.
Review_body: Everest did a fantastic job of blending two different movie styles together, the blockbuster style versus the documentary. If you are expecting to experience the same adrenaline rush as from watching movies with unreal plot of Man vs. Mountain, for instance Cliffhanger, you will not be satisfied with this film. Not that I didn't like watching Cliffhanger back then, it was a fun roller coaster ride, but Everest is a totally different beast all together as Rob Hall says in the movie.The emotions Everest brought out in my case was insecurity, hopelessness and sadness but also I felt the presence of the characters in the first part of the film really well. They are of course no superheroes, like in so many of the films today, but ordinary people, just like you and me, but still not that ordinary, since they are different from most of us. If you are willing to climb Mount Everest, something that I would not even consider, that is out of the ordinary.I guess I will never understand it why people feel the need to risk their lives in that way. I guess that most of us want to live as long as possible with our family and friends and try to stay out of danger as much as we can, but still taking chances in live, otherwise it would be rather dull, right? But then there are people who feel the need to tackle really risky environments, that most of us don't even consider and get a kick out of it, even if it means that they could get short-lived, i.e. live your live to the fullest no matter what. I can kind of see the appeal in that, I just choose not to take that road.I haven't read Into thin air" yet, but I will definitely be doing so, and most likely other books on this tragic event. I researched this tragedy online before I saw the film, so I came into it, knowing how it would end, but all the same, it was so intense. I can only imagine how it's going to affect people who know nothing of the story behind it, and are maybe expecting a happy ending, like in so many Hollywood movies today, i.e. going through a real struggle, but living to tell the tale.The pros of Everest are:Fantastic performances from the cast, especially from Jason Clarke and Josh Brolin. The cast did put themselves through a lot while filming this movie and they did a great job making the characters as REAL as possible. I really respect them for that. They really did earn their pay in my opinion. I don't think they will receive Oscar nominations since like so many critics have mentioned, there wasn't enough meat on the bone character wise in the movie in their opinions, and the characters are believed to be not so interesting", but I myself beg to differ.Unbelievably beautiful and effective cinematography. There were so many WOW moments but still not intrusive shots for show-off and it just flowed so well. I will be really surprised if Salvatore Totino will not be nominated for Cinematography.Great directing from Baltasar Kormakur, since this must have been a tremendous undertaking, both telling a true story without adding some extra for artistic purposes, i.e. sticking to the facts to respect the people involved and their families, and to decide to make it as authentic as possible by shooting it in harsh conditions as much as he could instead of relying mostly on CGI. In my opinion he should be nominated for best directing, but I'm not sure if it's realized how difficult the filming process really was.The sound was topnotch. The footfalls, the sound of the wind, the heavy breathing, the cracks in the icefall, the avalanches. It totally surrounded you in such a real way. The Dario Marianelli soundtrack blended so well that you hardly noticed it, which is a good thing, but I will be listening to it again later for sure.The con of Everest is:There is only one con in my opinion, and that is the ending. It ended kind of abruptly, like the director didn't feel the need to give the audience more than just a little glimpse of how the survivors and the families of those who died on the mountain fared after this tragedy.I highly recommend it if are looking for a movie that is both tense and beautiful, but above all as AUTHENTIC as a blockbuster can be.

****WARNING MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS***** Out of respect for the sterling cast of actors, they did a tremendous job bringing the cast of Adventure Consultants and Mountain Madness to life. We all know the plot, so the only thing this movie could really do was bring the infamous disaster to life using up-to-date technology. It's really just a reenactment.Unfortunately, the movie lacks the weight of truth. Rob Hall had known all along that the storm was coming. During weather meetings at Everest Base Camp, Rob Hall (alongside Scott Fischer) discussed highly accurate weather forecasts that were provided by the UK Met Office and the Danish Meteorological Institute. These forecasts predicted rising wind speeds beginning the 8th May 1997, reaching full intensity on the 11th. David Breashears and Ed Viesturs from the IMAX expedition knew too: Breashears himself had coordinated the weather forecasts from the UK Met Office in London even BEFORE leaving for Nepal. Rob Hall's unilateral decision making meant he kept his clients and guide Mike Groom out of the picture concerning the reality of an approaching storm. It's a miscarriage of justice that with such a bug budget, the movie fails to deliver the real punch and chooses instead to stick to the established narration we all know from Into Thin Air. Guess we'll never learn huh?Do yourself a favour: spend the movie money and get a copy of A Day to Die For by Graham Ratcliffe. If you want the truth, start there, not the cinema.

Having read the fabulous 'Into Thin Air' by Jon Krakauer I was excited to see posters around London promoting the film. The trailers certainly guaranteed a spectacular trip and the promise of 3d only added to my excitement. I watched the film last night but am sad to report that the film, as is often the case, failed to live up to the standards of the book. Those that have read Into Thin Air will find the main protagonist being changed, serious omissions of the dangers of the climb but more unforgiving, omissions of the sequence of coincidental events that led up to the fatal tragedy. The movie fails miserably in creating any emotional connection with the characters - Jon's character made largely insignificant. Scott Fischer is portrayed as a young hippie and Beck as nothing more than a loud mouth arrogant American with an estranged relationship with his wife. This lack of emotion ultimately sets the film up to fail as many of the protagonists meet their end. There is no shock and little empathy (perhaps none would be created if the movie had not started off by confirming it is based on a true event). The use of 3d effects is minimal which is a real shame as I felt this type of movie would have had great potential. There are few jolting moments and the ascent to Everest is portrayed as fun and easy rather than harrowing and arduous. All in all a film still worth watching in the cinema but best to keep expectations very low. This is neither a documentary nor an action adventure.

almost fell asleep in this film. cardboard characters, little or no plot except the obvious. 3d effects unimpressive and cannot understand why others rate it so highly.no excitement at all. the only person who may have been of interest was Doug the postman. why not build the film around him - he'd tried and failed 3 times before so how did he fail, what's his continuing motivation other than the obvious and where does a postman get the money to climb? that's how i would have approached the story. also Rob the leader says near the beginning that his decision is final and if they have to turn back it is his decision. but as soon as Doug starts whining he allows him to continue when conditions (the weather and Doug's) are so clearly against a successful summit bid. also the women in the film are an unnecessary distraction and have no real bearing on the story. at the end i couldn't have cared less who lived or died - just wanted to get home for a cup of tea.

We were hoping to see more of Sherpa people's life stories than some rich dudes climbing the mountain. Very bad that Hollywood chose to highlight Westerners in this movie. Very bad that there is very little shown about locals. No one liked it. We were all very disappointed. The movie is nothing about the place. It is all about how some rich people got into problem because of the weather.None of the school students like it.They should have made a movie about Sherpa people. Hollywood has become so shamelessly ignorant about diversity.

Review title: A well-document but spooky dream of every mountaineer.
Review_body: Well, the movie is a real life story without any external ingredients added to it to make it more interesting, which is the best part of the movie. Well shot and directed. Everest, the peak, has been shot beautifully. Best to watch it in 3D. As the climbing proceeds in stages, each stage has been shown in a distinct manner, such that one can enjoy each and every step of climbing Everest. Every emotion has been captured perfectly. Sometimes it becomes spooky for the people who are unaware of the risks on such slopes. But that is the thrilling part. The way deaths are filmed couldn't have been better. Everest is the dream of every mountaineer, whether be a trekker or the one who do expeditions, and this movie is the perfect treat for the one. Such a Nostalgia!!

The movie is good and the plot are excellent. Since it is based on real story so there is not much suspense or drama. The movie is very simple and understandable unlike other Hollywood movies. I will give 6 out of 10 to rate the movie But I found one flaw in the movie. when Rob Hall reached nepal and was travelling in local nepal bus in the bus. one Indian song was played named 'banno ke sahele'. This song is from a movie Kabhi Kushi Kabhi Gam which was released in the year 2001. But the everest disaster happened in 1996. five years before initial release of song. So I found this flaw in the movie. Overall movie is good. There is no such adventure or animation since movie is based on true story.

When I first saw the trailer of this movie, I had doubts whether this movie will live up to my expectations or not.But then I finally decided to give it a try. Thank god I gave it try.What a movie!!! What a realistic movie. It is too real to be called a movie.The Camera-work, Visuals are breath-taking, gut- wrecking yet overwhelming.Everything is great about this movie.One needs pure skill, courage and sheer will to even try for such a dangerous expedition. BUt sometimes skills and courage are not enough to survive, sometimes one is helpless in front of nature.I would like to congratulate the Director for Directing the Movie so beautifully(and being so technically sound).This movie is for the people who likes adventure and are brave heart, not for fragile hearted.I give this 10/10 , Really its that Good.

Review title: A film full of drama, which for the first time touches on the true cause of the tragedy, which up until recently had been kept from the public.
Review_body: A dramatic film shot in difficult conditions with a large number of characters to do justice to in a two hour film. The story is complex on many levels, a tall order for Baltasar to cover such colorful and larger than life individuals from an audience view point. The story line is not what many expected as he touches on the real cause behind what was an avoidable loss of life, the facts he subtly invites the audience to consider, which have been unknown by the public until recently, appear to have come from two books, 'A Day to Die For' and 'Left for Dead'. The absence of 'Into Thin Air' from the credits has surprised many, but this was a conscious decision by the Director and Producers. The dramatic scenery does not disappoint, although the film would have benefited from more lingering shots of Everest both at distance and zooming in.

Review title: The Climax is Not the Summit
Review_body: I recently watched this film to witness the tallest summit in the world. Everest stands 29,029 feet above sea level. This film is based on true events that took place on the May 1996 expedition. This has been a well know story that was depicted in the best- selling account of the expedition by Jon Krakauer's Into Thin Air. As the movie begins we see a few men traveling to Nepal that we learn to know as Beck, Doug, and Jon Krakauer. Soon after we are introduced to Rob Hall the guide for the team. I enjoy watching a movie that is based on true events first before reading about the films fact base. The reason being it adds to the natural emotions intended by the director. Since this story was not only published, but had taken place over 19years ago, it would be unwise to assume this story was already known. In my anticipation to watch this movie I read a review that explains the story line. Moreover, I came to find out this review had spoilers of the true events and read of 8 people dying on this mountain. Although, I had known 8 people died this day I was unaware of the popularity surrounding this day. May 10th has been the day Rob Hall had summited 4 years before. The film focuses on the clients of Rob Hall and their personal stories leading up the reason why they are all here to climb Everest. Rob was a well-known and respected guide to the summit due to his fame of summiting the most number of times. Others provided the nickname "Mountain Goat" or "Show" for Rob Hall. His date of climbing had also been known amongst the other guides as the day to summit. This is depicted in the movie and in each of the climbing books as one of the busiest days in each of the preceding years. This amount of traffic is one concern that is consistently discussed and highlighted on. There is a one-lane path to the summit known as the Hillary Step. This has been another bottleneck for climbers trying to summit since only a fixed number of climbers can be on the narrow pathway. Within the movie Rob Hall calls a meeting for the guides to discuss summiting on alternative days. These other guides were insulted to be told what day they can climb with their clients and the meeting was thereby ended. The film highlighted many facts about the mountain and the sickness that can come with the accent. Hall lays out the dangers of summiting Everest in his briefing to his team before they even set foot on the mountain. He explains, "Human beings are not designed to function at the cruising altitude of a 747. Your bodies will be literally dying." It is later found out that they individually paid a lot of money ($65,000 each) to get them to the top of Everest. Rob further discusses that the point is not to get to the top, but safely back down. The experience in my opinion made Everest seem as if you were told to wear a lead- suit and climb 200 steps in freezing temperatures. This is an annoyed, but understanding point of the events that took place. The movie focuses on the preparation of acclimatizing for a majority of the movie. Then some of the various teams are seen summiting after the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th camps cites. Unfortunately, this made the movie seem anticlimactic while at the summit. I was hopeful for more of an awe-inspiring scene or two leading up to the team's summit. Although, I felt that we were suddenly at the top of Everest there was more to this film. And if you knew the turn of events, you knew that the climax had only just begun. This film still managed to inspire me and teach a few ethical dilemmas we may face at some point in our lives. Works Cited:Everest. Dir. Baltasar Kormákur. Perf. Jason Clarke, Jake Gyllenhaal, Keira Knightley, Josh Brolin, Sam Worthington, Michael Kelly, John Hawkes and Emily Watson. 2015. Film.

I had to stop myself from bursting into tears. The emotional state of the situation that happened on 10th of May in 1996 is delivered, and leaves a profound mark in your conscience.While having some high-altitude mountaineering experience enables the viewer to get more sense of the sub-stories, just empathy and understanding that death cannot be negated will overwhelm you.
