This movie is not about sport, neither a guide to climbing top of the world, but a weep of sorrow, a scream of pain and unfathomable risks that climbers impose on themselves. When you start dying by just getting there, and every step you make can be your last one, what would you do in such a situation?

Boring, dull and full of unnecessary parts till the last part where the disaster struck on the way back. Jake Gyllenhaal was just grinning at everyone who says anything to him, and lying down topless at the base camp at EVEREST. I think that sums it up. Cannot believe Rob, the lead character, ignores everything he knows and succumbs to his emotions and dies as the result of his illogical actions. Probably the best part of it was to see the real characters that lived through (or could not unfortunately) the disaster that took place in 1996.

I just got home, and literally two hours ago, I was standing from my seat as the credits for "Everest" rolled up in theater, clapping with other audiences. The memory of the movie is still fresh in my mind, and coming out of theater was like coming out of an extravagant expedition of the highest mountain in the world, Sagarmatha (Mt. Everest).The first thing that impressed me was the photography or cinematography. When the crew lands on airport and tour the city of Kathmandu, the camera movement is done in such a brilliant manner that a Kathmandu resident like myself keeps on wondering - "Is this really my city?". But the real deal comes when they reach near Sagarmatha. Sagarmatha. The way the mountains are shown, it makes us feel we are really in the place. Then is the actual itinerary to the Everest summit. One has to pass through 4 camps, including the base camp to reach the top. And the writers of the movie has made sure that they get the location and terrain of these camps as close to real as possible. The scenery captured by the camera is wonderful, however, the story adds a cherry to the top. The brilliant story telling technique resulted in an emotional reception. The happiness in the people's face, and the way they reacted and they were shown by the camera, will be the scene I shall never, ever forget (Like the scene of Rose and Jack from Titanic). I recommend this movie to everyone out there who are impressed with great visual in cinema.

Review title: Anti Climatic, could of been much better then it was
Review_body: i was actually really looking forward to this movie, the premise seemed good, and the cast of actors seemed like a sure hit on paper, the finished product isn't so great which can be blamed on the films rating (pg) being constructing for what they could of done with it while the cinematography is breathtaking, and the actors mostly on point, what we get is a slow moving film, that really feels more a glorified reenactment of the what happens, then a Hollywood film. Everest moves at a sluggish pace all the way to end, while being predictable and bland throughout this film really struggles to know what it is, as it tentatively makes moves to be dramatic, slightly thriller with jump scares and nothing else much.I must say keeping track of the characters is rather hard as unless you see there faces, you mainly cant keep track of who is where, as they all were similar clothes, but credit is needed for trying to give back story to everyone in the main story, but you really don't form any emotional connection with any of the characters I cant stress how much this film could of either been an intense thriller or a serious drama and it would of been a hit instead your just waiting for this big tense climatic moment to come that never does, and suddenly after one scene more, it just end making it feel anticlimactic Hence the 5/10 RATING

Review title: WOW - no where near the real story
Review_body: This movie is filled with great scenes of the mountain, but could not even remotely stand close to the book. They don't concentrate on any one character for more then a few minutes and when people start to get left behind you don't really get any part of the real story. A huge break from even the made for TV movie which I thought was horrible but now would choose to watch that over this remake any day of the week. An awesome book, an awesome and sad story, a Hollywood version where the characters are flat. Sorry - I would give this a 0 if it were an option. Go out and watch the original and read the book because you need it to follow this story.

A visualy stunning disaster movie. The first half is pretty entertaining but from there it just goes down the mountain. The movie feels like they wanted to make a documentary and drama at the same time but it failed to develop. And then there are so many characters that after a while you can't even keep track of them and you won't care if they live or die they wanted to give each character a backstory and reason why they are climbing the world's biggest mountain but instead of that they should have focused on Rob Hall and his heroism and how he didn't wanted to leave anyone behind. Oh and Josh Brolin's character got a lot more attention than he deserved. In conclusion it wasn't a bad movie you won't feel like you have wasted 2 hours of your life.

Review title: Everest: Cool shots, not much more
Review_body: To start, there are some positives in the film. The cinematography is excellent, with both the real-life backgrounds and CGI sequences blending very well. Along with this, the film also does a good job with creating an atmosphere for the audience. Things such as the special effects and the sound editing help to involve the audience in the film and make it seem, to some extent, that they are there on the mountain with the characters.Aside from the previously mentioned things, nothing in the film exceeds mediocrity. There are attempts in the first half of the film to set up an emotional backstory and a family subplot for multiple characters. However, so little time is spent on the topics that they come off feeling completely unnecessary. This is made worse due to the fact that the family elements actually end up being revisited and take up a considerable amount of time in the final act of the film.The script and performances by the cast range from average to bad and never really exceed what you would expect from a summer blockbuster. This is made even more disappointing because Jake Gyllenhaal, one of the most talented actors working today, was wasted in the film, barely filling and screen time.Finally, the characters in the film are in constant danger, which is suppose to be the main "thrilling" element that is suppose to engage the audience. However, due to the lack of depth given to each character, it just leaves you not caring about the fates of the characters. Also, due to the large number of characters in the film, it is hard to keep track of their faces, let alone their names. This is especially true during the chaotic parts of the film, when you can barely see anything, let alone the faces of the people in the film.Overall, "Everest" looks very nice, but nothing else in the film is done particularly well, with it never being able to exceed the level of a below average summer Hollywood blockbuster.

There were a number of excellent actors in this film and it was a very good story to make into a film. I ultimately found that, despite the dramatic real life story, the film missed opportunities to push for a very viseral experience. There were moments that certainly could have and should have been more drawn out to give the viewer a truer experience to what the real life story was based on. The film is certainly worth watching, but it is not one that I would return to for another viewing.
In the starting minutes of the movie(6:07) a music which is played is released in 2001 and according to movie its 30th march 1996. So how it can be played. A big mistake to notice.
